qas.question: Which language was used in lectures in early European universities?
For what subjects did professors use the work of Hippocrates?
What type of subjects did the universities of northern Europe focus on?
What type of degree was given out at a English university?
What developed differently in eastern and western Europe?
What language was used for university texts and lectures but not disputations and examinations?

plausible_answers.text: in the south students often went on to professional positions.

qas.question: Why did southern universities mostly award bachelor's degrees?
Who did universities in southern Italy model their self regulating pattern after?
Which language was used in lectures in art universities?
For what subjects did professors use the work of Bolonga?
What types of subjects did the universities of Bolonga focus on?
What type of degree was given out at the University of Bolonga?
What type of degree would one likely get in iberia?

context: <b4_0>The university culture<b4_0/> developed differently in northern Europe than it did in the south, although the northern (primarily Germany, France and Great Britain) and southern universities (primarily Italy) did have many elements in common. <a0_0><b5_0><b9_0>Latin<b9_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> was the language of the university, used for all texts, lectures, disputations and examinations. <b6_0>Professors<b6_0/> lectured on the books of Aristotle for logic, natural philosophy, and metaphysics; while Hippocrates, Galen, and Avicenna were used for <a1_0><b10_0>medicine<b10_0/><a1_0/>. Outside of these commonalities, great differences separated north and south, primarily in subject matter. Italian universities focused on law and medicine, while the northern universities focused on the <a2_0><b11_0>arts and theology<b11_0/><a2_0/>. There were distinct differences in the quality of instruction in these areas which were congruent with their focus, so scholars would travel north or south based on their interests and means. There was also a difference in the types of degrees awarded at these universities. English, French and German universities usually awarded <a3_0><b12_0>bachelor's degrees<b12_0/><a3_0/>, with the exception of degrees in theology, for which the <b13_0>doctorate<b13_0/> was more common. Italian universities awarded primarily doctorates. The distinction can be attributed to the intent of the degree holder after graduation – in the north the focus tended to be on acquiring teaching positions, while <b7_0>in the south students often went on to professional positions.<b7_0/> The structure of northern universities tended to be modeled after the system of faculty governance developed at the University of Paris. Southern universities tended to be patterned after the student-controlled model begun at the <b8_0>University of Bologna.<b8_0/> Among the southern universities, a further distinction has been noted between those of northern Italy, which followed the pattern of Bologna as a "self-regulating, independent corporation of scholars" and those of southern Italy and Iberia, which were "founded by royal and imperial charter to serve the needs of government."
